importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication marks the latest update on global efforts to improve disaster alerts amid increasing extreme weather events.

This date refers to the warning about the imminent collapse of a mountain glacier in Switzerland, which prompted the evacuation of the village of Blatten and highlights real-time monitoring as a life-saving measure.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The article emphasizes that 2025 has seen a surge in major weather-related disasters globally, including floods in Pakistan, Nigeria, and South Korea, and wildfires in southern Europe and the US, illustrating the urgency of early warning systems.

keyTakeAways: Nearly half of all countries lack early-warning systems for extreme weather, leaving millions—especially in developing nations—vulnerable to climate-related disasters.
Disaster-related deaths are six times higher in countries without early-warning systems, with 90% of such deaths occurring in developing countries over the past 50 years.
The WMO reports that over 2 million people have died due to weather, water, and climate-related hazards in the last 50 years, with most deaths in fragile and conflict-affected regions.
While 108 countries now use multi-hazard early warning systems (up from 52), half still have only basic capacity and 16% have less than basic capacity.
Progress is being seen in Africa, with more countries establishing functioning websites and standardized alert systems.
Early warning systems enable early action and are critical to saving lives and protecting economic infrastructure as extreme weather intensifies due to climate change.
The Swiss glacier collapse in May 2025 demonstrated the value of continuous monitoring and timely evacuation, reinforcing the need for global early-warning networks.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The UN, through its World Meteorological Organization (WMO), is a central authority pushing for global early-warning systems to combat rising extreme weather events linked to climate change.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The WMO released a report urging countries to improve their disaster early-warning systems, citing a growing threat from extreme weather due to climate change.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The World Meteorological Organization (WMO), under the UN, has issued a global call to action for improved early-warning systems for extreme weather, noting that nearly half of all countries lack sufficient capacity, with devastating consequences—particularly in developing nations where disaster-related deaths are six times higher without such systems. Over 2 million people have died from weather, water, and climate hazards in the past 50 years, mostly in developing countries. While progress has been made, with 108 countries now using early-warning systems (up from 52), half still have only basic or less than basic systems. The article highlights recent disasters in 2025—including floods in Pakistan, Nigeria, and South Korea, and wildfires in southern Europe and the US—as evidence of the escalating crisis. A key case study is the May 2025 glacier collapse in Switzerland, which prompted the evacuation of the village of Blatten, demonstrating how real-time monitoring enables life-saving actions. The WMO stresses that early warning systems are not just about alerts, but about empowering communities to take preventive action, especially in fragile, conflict-affected, and climate-vulnerable regions.
title: UN pushes for worldwide disaster alerts as extreme weather ‘spirals’
